Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Digitization TCN: InvertEBase: Reaching Back to See the Future: Species-rich Invertebrate Faunas Document Causes and Consequences of Biodiversity Shifts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The rapid biodiversity change in North America has significant effects on essential ecosystem services, from impact on soil health and nutrient cycling, to agriculture, forestry and water quality. Exploding populations of invasive species threaten fresh water and terrestrial habitats and potentially impact the natural resources of the nation. Easy access to robust, expertly vetted baseline data for species occurrences, abundances, and distribution ranges, and monitoring how these parameters have changed through time, will facilitate the protection of the nation's natural resources, and vastly improve the capacity for effective restoration, land management planning, and conservation management. Numerous undergraduate students will receive training in digitization technologies and a modular exhibit will be developed to engage public interest in biodiversity changes.

Effective monitoring requires easy electronic access to historical specimen baseline information for temporal and regional species diversity comparisons that can facilitate informed land management decisions. Vast amounts of specimen data are housed within the nation's natural history collections, but most of these data are not readily accessible from digital resources. Size and complexity of scientific specimen collections require major technological advances in capturing specimen data. The goal of this four-year collaborative project is the rapid digitization of >2 million specimens and their locality data from ten arthropod and mollusk collections housed at six major US museums in six states (Il, OH, AL,MI, DE, PA). This project will significantly automate specimen data capture by utilizing optical character and voice-recognition technologies. The digitized data from this project will be immediately deployed for habitat-based distribution modeling and analyses.This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most people experience natural history museums through the public-facing exhibit spaces, but the scientific core of these museums is contained in huge libraries of preserved specimens and fossils that have been amassed since the 1800s. These behind-the-scenes research collections are large and growing resources that are essential for documenting biodiversity over space and time.   

The Delaware Museum of Natural History (DMNH) cares for over 2 million mollusk specimens in its research collection, with particularly important collections of freshwater mussels, terrestrial snails, and marine mollusks including snails, bivalves, squids and octopods.  Prior to this project, none of the data associated with these specimens were available on the web or in data portals. The only way to access this information was by corresponding with collections staff or coming to the museum for hands-on study.

The InvertEBase Thematic Collections Network (TCN) changed the way DMNH shares data with the scientific and general public.  InvertEBase was a collaborative project designed to digitize specimen records from ten research collections housed at six major US museums.  The goal was to make over 3 million specimens of terrestrial and freshwater mollusks and arthropods of eastern North America available in data portals. These groups were chosen because they contain many species, they are abundant, and they are ecologically important.  In particular, many of these species are sensitive to environmental perturbations such as climate change, habitat loss, or competition with non-native species.

At DMNH, the InvertEBase TCN project facilitated the update and improvement of over 78,000 records of land and freshwater mollusks, representing over 800,000 individual specimens.  Data records were transitioned from a simple spreadsheet format to a relational database that allows for efficient daily management (Specify).  During this process, DMNH updated the dataset to reflect new taxonomic names, filled in missing information including latitude and longitude of collecting sites, and standardized names and localities so all relevant records are returned when an end user searches the data.

DMNH now publishes these data at web-based data portals including Symbiota (InvertEBase.org), iDigBio (iDigBio.org) and the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF.org).  These data records are now easy to access and available for students, researchers or the interested public to browse and use.  

The intellectual merit of making so much data available is twofold.  First, it provides easy access to a primary dataset of expertly vetted and critically improved biodiversity data.  These data can be freely used by researchers, educators, conservationists, resource managers, and the general public as their needs require. Secondly, these collections allow researchers to reach back in time to examine historical species occurrences and develop baselines of biodiversity.  These baselines are essential to answering questions about how species occurrences, abundances, and distributions change over time in response to perturbations including climate change, habitat loss, and non-native species.

The InvertEBase project also provided opportunities for DMNH to talk with the public about the value of natural history collections, and to teach undergraduates, museum staff, and volunteers about why we have and care for such large collections.  DMNH created a stand-alone exhibit ?Little Creatures, Big Data? to use in the galleries and at special events.  This 6-panel exhibit provides insights on why natural history collections are important, why digitization is an essential part of caring for the specimens, and how these organisms can be used for research and education. Finally, newly-mobilized data was immediately integrated into a new course based undergraduate research experience (CURE) that was co-developed and taught with Widener University faculty. Students in this upper-level ecology class used digitized data to develop and test hypotheses about freshwater bivalve biodiversity in the Duck River, Tennessee.
